description:
Day one shit in my classes is what I refer to as ‘the responsibilities of a philosopher’ - rationalism, fallibility, and most importantly, skepticism. ⁣
⁣
At my most conservative, I’m a radical skeptic, meaning I immediately dismiss anything that can be doubted, and at my most extreme, I can be an outright epistemic nihilist, which essentially means  I doubt the possibility of any knowledge altogether.⁣
⁣
Using these principles, I personally like to navigate through ideas that are considered taboo by many in philosophy - questioning the possibility of the Illuminati is how I became a philosopher.⁣
⁣
I may get scoffed at by ‘professional’ philosophers for doing so, but that’s cool, cuz most of them uphold colonial structures that were exposed via such practices anyways.⁣
It was, after all, once considered a conspiracy to think that the government suppressed information and indoctrinated students to homogenous ways of thinking - ie ‘how to become a ‘’proper’’ American’ - and now there are entire courses taught about how to help students - and ourselves - recover from such brainwashing.⁣
⁣
Reality is crazy AF, and excluding ideas you don’t agree with simply because they challenge your predetermined conception of it is a dangerous slope - it is the mark of an intelligent mind to entertain ideas that you don’t agree with 💀💀.
